sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine ‚Äî For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: VS Code can be supercharged wuth hundreds of [VS Code extensions](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/05/useful-vs-code-extensions-web-developers/). In this article, Leonardo shares four useful extensions that help him in his daily work.

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: How can we make disabled buttons more inclusive? When do they work well, and when do they fail on us? And finally, when do we actually need them, and how can we avoid them? Let‚Äôs find out.
articles.title: Frustrating Design Patterns: Disabled Buttons

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Arihant Verma)
articles.description: In this article, we‚Äôll discuss and learn about the use case of iterating over React `children` and the ways to do it. In particular, we will deep dive into one of the utility methods, `React.Children.toArray`, that React gives us, which helps to iterate over the children in a way which ensures performance and determinism.
articles.title: React Children And Iteration Methods

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Callum Hart)
articles.description: Resilience is intrinsic to the web and therefore us, web developers. This article explores how graceful degradation, defensive coding, observability, and a healthy attitude towards failures better equips us before, during, and after an error occurs.
articles.title: How To Build Resilient JavaScript UIs

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: In this article, we‚Äôll take a deep dive into the refactoring process itself, and cover incremental refactoring strategy, visual regression testing, and maintaining the refactored codebase.
articles.title: Refactoring CSS: Strategy, Regression Testing And Maintenance (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: New month, new wallpapers! In this post, you‚Äôll find unique and inspiring wallpapers for August 2021. Created with love by the community for the community, they come in versions with and without a calendar for the month.
articles.title: Good Vibes In August (2021 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)
articles.description: Having an e-commerce store is crucial for any store owner as more and more customers are turning to online shopping. In this tutorial, we shall go through how to create an e-commerce site with Angular 11. The site will use the Commerce Layer as a headless e-commerce API and use Paypal to process payments.
articles.title: How To Build An E-Commerce Site With Angular 11, Commerce Layer And Paypal

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Elad Shechter)
articles.description: What are absolute units? What are the differences between relative and absolute units, and how do we create accurate sizes on the web? In this article, Elad Shechter explains why CSS absolute units aren‚Äôt so absolute.
articles.title: There Is No Such Thing As A CSS Absolute Unit

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kitty Giraudel)
articles.description: Dialogs are everywhere in modern interface design (for good or for bad), and yet many of them are not accessible to assistive technologies. In this article, we will dig into how to create a short script to create accessible dialogs.
articles.title: Creating An Accessible Dialog From Scratch

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alexander Dubovoy)
articles.description: Next.js has strong opinions about how to organize JavaScript but not CSS. How can we develop patterns that encourage best CSS practices while also following the framework‚Äôs logic? The answer is surprisingly simple ‚Äî to write well-structured CSS that balances global and local styling concerns.
articles.title: Global vs. Local Styling In Next.js

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Scanlon)
articles.description: Gatsby recently announced the launch of ‚Äúfunctions‚Äù. In this article, Paul Scanlon explains how to get the current location of the International Space Station (ISS) as it orbits the Earth in real-time using [Gatsby Functions](https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/reference/functions/) and then display it on a 3D interactive globe using [React Three Fibre](https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-fiber).
articles.title: Gatsby Serverless Functions And The International Space Station

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Many web design agencies consider it a badge of honor that they win work exclusively through word-of-mouth recommendations. In this article, Paul Boag explains why that is entirely the wrong attitude and what to do about it.
articles.title: A Guide To Attracting Clients To Your Agency

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Matthew Talebi)
articles.description: Are you running a business and have too many things going on at once? Meetings, bugs, customer feedback, new clients in addition to your already tight deadlines? Let‚Äôs face it, time management is hard, and it becomes even more difficult in the trying times we are in.
articles.title: Adding Time To Your Schedule As A Professional

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Do you need a little inspiration boost? We‚Äôve collected some useful color tools and resources that we‚Äôve discovered lately ‚Äî to help you get the most out of your creativity. We‚Äôve also just recently covered [CSS auditing tools](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/css-auditing-tools/), [CSS generators](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/css-generators/), [accessible front-end components](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/complete-guide-accessible-front-end-components/), [front-end boilerplates](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/06/useful-frontend-boilerplates-starter-kits/) and [VS code extensions](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/05/useful-vs-code-extensions-web-developers/) ‚Äî you might find them useful, too.

Rem


Root element's font size. In other words, it is the font size of the html element.

Disclaimer: In this article I list the key points I consider every time I do a code review. This is not a step by step guide on how to do code reviews. I don't expect everyone to agree with the statements below. Finally, English is not my first language, so my apologies for any mistakes.
Code reviews is the time of judgment (this meant to be a joke) - it's the place where you give the opportunity to other developers to validate the piece of code you proudly worked on. Regardless you are a junior or senior developer, there will always be something you might have missed in your code, or could be written in a better way.
There are times where code reviews turn to be a battlefield between the reviewer and the code author though. But this should not be the case. Remember, the result of a code r‚Ä¶
articles.title: Code review - the mature way

articles.author: Julien Maury
articles.description:
Let's talk about accessibility overlays.
I'm referring to automated codes that are supposed to "handle" the accessibility part. Many of those tools miss most accessibility errors that jeopardize the use of assistive technology.
For example, some projects use toolbars or javaScript plugins to make the website more accessible without changing the source code.
There are many overlays out there. Some are generic, and others focus on specific impairments, such as cognitive disabilities or visual diseases.
For example, if you have dyslexia, specific fonts and magnifiers are supposed to improve your experience by applying a different letter spacing.
This way, websites may pass some tests that follow the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG).
It's way better than nothing, but it's not enough‚Ä¶
articles.title: Is a11y your ally?

articles.author: Michael Primo
articles.description:
What have I done today?


I managed to try some new mechanics and hazards, like deadly blocks and changing layouts of the map with one button and also screen wrap. I think to remove jumps and use better the level's gimmicks. I tried even stuff like bouncing, dashing and reducing to zero the gravity but that doesn't work for now. I wanted to change palettes but I think to stick with that one. Hope to finish testing tomorrow and starting making officially the game.

articles.author: Mekarosi
articles.description:
I was fortunate to have a mentor guiding me and pointing out the pitfalls while learning to code. At that time, I was tempted to believe that I could learn to code in 3 months and become proficient. However, the truth is learning a programming language is similar to learning any human language, such that you have to start by learning the ABC (alphabets), syntax, and logic.
Most beginners usually believe that learning to code is a piece of cake. They glance through it and assume that is the best method.
Deliberate practice and often guided by an expert skilled coach or mentor (someone with an expert eye), according to bestselling author Daniel Golemon, these coaches and mentors are offering feedback in specific ways to improve and without such feedback, you don‚Äôt get to the top ranks. This ‚Ä¶
articles.title: LEARN TO CODE AS AN ABSOLUTE BEGINNER

articles.author: Arnaud Leymet
articles.description:
Hello there ( ò‚Äø ò)‚ïØ
Chosing what will compose a stack is both a matter of experience, opinion and timing.
Experience helps identifying what will stick, but opinion has a major role in the final chosing.
As of timing, what seems to be a good idea at the time, may be compromised by a lack of maintainers goodwill or vision a year later.
So by no means is the LOLstack The Perfect Stack‚Ñ¢Ô∏è. Now that's out, let's cover what it has to offer.
TL;DR: Enough with the stalling, Access the good stuff
An App, an API, a Database and all of the in-between that make an App and its stack work.




Category
Tech used





Mobile app that targets iOS, Android & the web

React Native Expo




Design system for a component-based, modular & consistent design

Eva Design UI Kitten




Typing for a type-safe runtim‚Ä¶
articles.title: Building an App üì± and its Stack in minutes with LOLstack ü•°

articles.author: Arnaud Leymet
articles.description:
Hello there ( ò‚Äø ò)‚ïØ
So this ü§™ crazy app idea has been growing in your head lately. Yet nothing has been done about it, as you don't see clearly how nor when building it.
Business and Market reasons aside, the most common reasons (/cough excuses) not starting working on your crazy idea Minimum Viable Product (MVP) are in my opinion:
üßç‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Being alone
Ok you don't have a team yet, but suck it on.
‚åõ Takes too much time
Sure. Creating something new and different takes time. But what if? is took less than expected?
üò´ Technology fatigue
Behind hypes, technology cycles and experts contradictory opinions, there can be some technology fatigue, which will tickle beginners to tech veterans.
what if the fatigue were no more?
ü§Ø Cognitive complexity
It's actually sane to think that there is a lot of area to cover for an app to work, and that a lot of knowledge in multiple areas are needed. On top of the actual app development, there is also the question of the database, of the APIs, of the security, authentication, production debugging, etc.
what if this cognitive complexity were already tackled by others?
Are you thinking of a 5th reason? Please drop your suggestions in the comments üí¨



What if all these reasons were no more? (Well... Apart being alone, you're on your own mate)
As lots of us have been tickering, playing and working with lots of technology bits, some of us have converged all this know-how into ready-to-use stacks, that help bootstrapping your next projects.
At codename, we have been developing our take of what a stack should be.
Featuring LOLstack, your ready-to-dev & ready-to-deploy software stack.
Building an App Was Hard. ü§Ø Now Stop Making Excuses.
articles.title: Building an App Was Hard. ü§Ø But Stop Making Excuses.

articles.author: Clean Code Studio
articles.description:
10 Tips for Clean Code











@cleancodestudio

      
Not your organization.
Not your manager.
Not your team.
You.
    






  
@cleancodestudio

      
Ask yourself: ‚ÄúCan I write code that expresses this comment so I can remove this comment?‚Äù
    





  
@cleancodestudio

      
Clean code does one thing, 
does it well, and does it only.
    





  
@cleancodestudio

      
 Less code is less buggy.
Less code is less onboarding.
Less code is less maintenance.
Less Code = Less Liability.
Clean Code is minimalistic.
    





  
@cleancodestudio

      
Ex: Use verbs to name functions.
    





  
@cleancodestudio

      
Nothing is ever done, iteratively make code better.
    





  
@cleancodestudio

      
Follow Clean Code Studio on Twitter for more!






More Clean Code Tips
(Note: Dev.to wouldn't let me put all 10 Clean Code twitter tips in this post. Remaining tips are posted in the comments section!)
articles.title: 10 Tips For Clean Code

1-Sentence-Summary: 75 Hard is a fitness challenge and book that teaches mental toughness by making you commit to five daily critical tasks for 75 days straight, including drinking a gallon of water, reading 10 pages of a non-fiction book, doing two 45-minute workouts, taking a progress picture, and following a diet.
